subject: Investing
title: Stock Buybacks Explained
description: A 60-second lesson on Stock Buybacks Explained.

hook.text: Apple spent $600 billion buying back its own stock over a decade. Why would a company buy itself?

buildup.text: A buyback reduces shares outstanding. Fewer shares means each remaining share is worth a bigger piece.

discovery.text: Buybacks boost EPS without growing profits. They also return cash to shareholders without triggering dividend tax.

twist.text: Critics say buybacks inflate stock prices artificially. Executives with stock options benefit the most.

climax.text: US companies now spend more on buybacks than dividends. It's become the dominant way to return capital.

punchline.text: Buybacks shrink the pie's slices so each one gets bigger.

quiz.question: How do stock buybacks benefit remaining shareholders?
options: Each share represents a larger ownership stake
